title: 'My goal is to race at the top levels of motorsport': Reema Juffali, Saudi Arabia's first female professional racing driver, is creating a real buzz
text:
When Saudi Arabia lifted its decades-long ban on females driving in June last year, sparking cautious hopes that the kingdom’s systemic oppression of women’s rights might one day be consigned to history, Reema Juffali was preparing for her most important race yet.

The softly spoken 27-year old, who was born and raised in Jeddah, is the country’s first female professional racing driver. She made one of her first appearances in the F4 British Championships at Brands Hatch last October. This weekend Juffali is back at the historic 2.4-mile circuit in Kent, driving for Double R Racing, the Woking-based team formed in 2004 by 2007 Formula One champion Kimi Raikkonen and his race manager, Steve Robertson.

“I wouldn’t say I’m nervous,” Juffali, who now lives between London and Jeddah, says about the the season closer. “I’m excited.”

Juffali is already starting to create somewhat of a buzz when she turns up to compete, mainly because it’s still so rare to see a woman in the cockpit. In early August, while preparing to race at Snetterton in Norfolk, a steady stream of spectators – many of them young families – were stopping by Double R’s paddock to snap pictures of her.

Juffali’s passion for fast cars dates back to her teenage years. She attended the International School of Jeddah where she completed the International Baccalaureate programme and was an avid athlete who watched Formula One in her spare time.
